page.title: 04CONONLEY LEAD MINE:1
page.content: The remains of Cononley lead mine can be found on the moors of Cononley and Glusburn. The Royalties of Cononley moor belong to the Duke of Devonshire. Permission was first given to work the mine by Henry V111 in 1530 AD but it is not known when the mining actually began. The population of the village of Cononley increased to over 1,500 inhabitants due to the influx of miners from Derbyshire, Cornwall and Wales. The large increase in the population and the pollution from the mine water forced the Duke of Devonshire to build new water supplies. The new wells were built by public subscription and were placed by the institute, the Co_op, Cross Farm and Calverts Lane.
